channel.title: Arrays. (Strings)
channel.description:
[b]Purpose:[/b] [i]To teach you how to use string arrays and to teach you all the methods in the Java API that you can use.[/i] [b]Definition of an Array:[/b] [i][size=10pt]A series of variables (or objects) that are of the same type and size. Each of these variables (objects) are indexed; individual elements are called array elements.[/size][/i] [size=6pt]-orafaq.cs.rmit.edu.au/glossary/faqglosa.htm[/size] [b]Arrays in Java:[/b] Arrays can be declared in quite a few ways in the java programming language. This tutorial is aimed at coders with limited coding knowledge about arrays. This diagram explains an array in a visual way. Which might just help some people understand them more clearly. [img]http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/figures/java/objects-tenElementArray.gif[/img] The ways to delcare them followed by explainations: [code]String[] eg1;[/code] This creates a array of string with no set amount of indexs. And none on the values have been initialized. Which means you will get a compile error so you must set the length of it or specify a specific line on elements. So in this case we do the following. [code]eg1 = new String[15][/code] Which creates an array of strings with 16 indices. See the next example for more detail/information. [code]String eg2 = new String[6];[/code] This creates an array with a set amount of indices. In this case 7 because all arrays start with and include 0. You can then set the values of the indices. [code] eg1[0] = 50; //Elven Lord - We specify which index when we set the value of the object. eg1[1] = 45; eg2[0] = 75; eg2[1] = 80; //Elven Lord - Some as eg1.. [/code] [u]Arrays with set Values[/u] You can also set the values of the array indexs within curly braces ({ }). [code]String[] eg3; //Elven Lord - An uninitialized array.[/code] This is no different to eg1. Its really the same thing. An uninitialized array... [code]String[] eg4 = {10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20};[/code] This Example is however a lot different. It sets the indices and the length in this way. There are 7 indices, 0-6. All the values of the indices have already been set within the braces and each value seperated by commas.
String[][][][] eg5 = {{{{"a", "d", "c", "z"}, {"y", "l", "p"}, {"a", "d", "p", "m"}, {"x", "a", "o"}}}};
Now this is somewhat different to all of them. This is an array of arrays also known as a multidimensional array. This isn't so commonly used. As shown in the colours it shows which line is equalled to which. I used colours so it was much more clear. As you can see each set of []'s has a corresponding set of braces. All the indices of each set of arrays have been initialized. [b]Note:[/b] [i]Always before compiling check your arrays are correct because [u]all[/u] arrays start at and include 0.[/i] [b]Links:[/b] [i][url=http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/arrays.html]The Java[sup]TM[/sup] Tutorial - Arrays Tutorial[/url][/i] [b]Credits:[/b] - Google define Option. - The Java[sup]TM[/sup] Tutorials. - Myself (Elven Lord). [size=8pt][i]IF THERE ARE ANY ERRORS. POST THE MISTAKES TO MAKE IT 100% ACCURATE.[/i][/size]

item.title: Arrays. (Strings)
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote author=Taharok link=topic=199574.msg1783318#msg1783318 date=1190874941]
It should be:

String[][][][] arrayArrayArrayArray1 = {{{{"a", "d", "c", "z"}, { "b", "e", "d", "a" }}}}

yeps what he sayd all the current colored 1ns are 4rth dimensions correct?

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays. (Strings)
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:16, topic:145752”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=199574.msg1778358#msg1778358 date=1190689600]

pizza pie and nueb35, trying to make yourselves look better than him by showing all the mistakes he made, eh? All he did was read through the Sun tutorial on arrays and rewrite it in his own words. There is nothing wrong with that imo. And, a slightly modified anonymous quote:

“Teaching is like learning twice”

well in his post it clearly says “IF THERE ARE ANY ERRORS. POST THE MISTAKES TO MAKE IT 100% ACCURATE.” i dont need to post mistakes to show im better than ppl but realy thats not my reason of posting them

Well that’s good and all, but sometimes people go over the top when they are no longer being put down by others themselves, if you nomisain.
[/quote]
I understand, but is that not what everyone in this “community” does?

This is a good tutorial though. I could maybe read some of it for some reason.[/quote]

So, that’s why you have been so weird lately, Jumped on the bandwagon, have you?

[quote="† ElvenLord †, post:17, topic:145752"][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=199574.msg1778295#msg1778295 date=1190688007]
Uhhh, the color coordination on the 4D array is wrong.
[/quote]

Correction plz?[/quote]

It should be:

[quote]
String[][][][] arrayArrayArrayArray1 = {{{{“a”, “d”, “c”, “z”}, { “b”, “e”, “d”, “a” }}}}

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:8, topic:145752”][quote author=† ElvenLord † link=topic=199574.msg1775544#msg1775544 date=1190555270]
…

String[] eg3; //Elven Lord - An uninitialized array.

This is no different to eg1. Its really the same thing. An uninitialized array…

String[] eg4 = {10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20);

This Example is however a lot different. It sets the indices and the length in this way. There are 7 indices, 0-6. All the values of the indices have already been set within the braces and each value seperated by commas.

[quote]String[][][][] eg5 = {{{{“a”, “d”, “c”, “z”},
{“y”, “l”, “p”},
{“a”, “d”, “p”, “m”},
{“x”, “a”, “o”}}}};[/quote]

…
[/quote]

Take wild guess…

Look at the bolded one!!!

String[] eg4 = {10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20 };

not

String[] eg4 = {10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20 );

ohh and u just notice that it ends with ) not that its an int array? “10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20”

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays. (Strings)
item.dc:creator: @_ElvenLord † ElvenLord †
item.description:
@_ElvenLord wrote:

Purpose: To teach you how to use string arrays and to teach you all the methods in the Java API that you can use.

Definition of an Array:
[size=10pt]A series of variables (or objects) that are of the same type and size. Each of these variables (objects) are indexed; individual elements are called array elements.[/size]
[size=6pt]-orafaq.cs.rmit.edu.au/glossary/faqglosa.htm[/size]

Arrays in Java:

Arrays can be declared in quite a few ways in the java programming language. This tutorial is aimed at coders with limited coding knowledge about arrays. This diagram explains an array in a visual way. Which might just help some people understand them more clearly.

The ways to delcare them followed by explainations:

String[] eg1;

This creates a array of string with no set amount of indexs. And none on the values have been initialized. Which means you will get a compile error so you must set the length of it or specify a specific line on elements.

So in this case we do the following.

eg1 = new String[15]

Which creates an array of strings with 16 indices. See the next example for more detail/information.

String eg2 = new String[6];

This creates an array with a set amount of indices. In this case 7 because all arrays start with and include 0.

You can then set the values of the indices.

eg1[0] = 50; //Elven Lord - We specify which index when we set the value of the object.
eg1[1] = 45;

eg2[0] = 75; 
eg2[1] = 80; //Elven Lord - Some as eg1..

Arrays with set Values

You can also set the values of the array indexs within curly braces ({ }).

String[] eg3; //Elven Lord - An uninitialized array.

This is no different to eg1. Its really the same thing. An uninitialized array…

String[] eg4 = {10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20};

This Example is however a lot different. It sets the indices and the length in this way. There are 7 indices, 0-6. All the values of the indices have already been set within the braces and each value seperated by commas.

String[][][][] eg5 = {{{{"a", "d", "c", "z"}, {"y", "l", "p"}, {"a", "d", "p", "m"}, {"x", "a", "o"}}}};

Now this is somewhat different to all of them. This is an array of arrays also known as a multidimensional array. This isn’t so commonly used. As shown in the colours it shows which line is equalled to which. I used colours so it was much more clear. As you can see each set of []'s has a corresponding set of braces. All the indices of each set of arrays have been initialized.

Note: Always before compiling check your arrays are correct because all arrays start at and include 0.

Links:
The Java[sup]TM[/sup] Tutorial - Arrays Tutorial

Credits:

  • Google define Option.
  • The Java[sup]TM[/sup] Tutorials.
  • Myself (Elven Lord).

[size=8pt]IF THERE ARE ANY ERRORS. POST THE MISTAKES TO MAKE IT 100% ACCURATE.[/size]

Read full topic
